discussion.content:
Actually, I think this is one of the few Comptia questions that's pretty straightforward, its almost just a vocabulary question. The definition of Data Minimization fits this exact question, i'm not sure how you could think the answer could be anything else. 

The principle of data minimization involves limiting data collection to only what is required to fulfill a specific purpose.

Answer D: The problem with answer B is that the question does not elude to a "lack" of overall security (even though it discusses the DBA's responsibilities as such). Also, concur that Data Minimization relates to collection, but it is probably safe to assume that 1 record collect equal 1 record stored, so I'd argue that the words are interchangeable here. Thanks again for CompTIA's vague verbiage!

Maybe: B. PII security?
I don't see how B could be incorrect. At first I thought that "data minimization" was a better answer,, because it was more specific. But data minimization seems to be about how much data is collected, not how data is stored.

comments.content: "A manager directs the administrator to reduce the number of unique instances of PII stored"

questions.question_text:
A database administrator is required to adhere to and implement privacy principles when executing daily tasks. A manager directs the administrator to reduce the number of unique instances of PII stored within an organization's systems to the greatest extent possible.
Which of the following principles is being demonstrated?

A newly hired security analyst has joined an established SOC team. Not long after going through corporate orientation, a new attack method on web-based applications was publicly revealed. The security analyst immediately brings this new information to the team lead, but the team lead is not concerned about it.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for the team lead's position?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. The attack type does not meet the organizationג€™s threat model.
I would make more sense if the team member wasn't worried about the threat because it's not in their model. I'm going with B.

comments.content:
Threat models should be continuously updated. If "a new attack method on web-based applications was publicly revealed." It might be worth considering updating your threat model. 
No sane organization would just ignore a threat because it doesn't match their present threat model. What if there was a serious ransomware threat? That could cost tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands. If the team lead cares about his/her career, he/she would not ignore a serious threat.

discussion.content: Regarding Answer A: As a systems engineer, I hate to say this, but this question does come from the vantage point of the "Security Analyst and his/her Security Team Lead" - remember that their primary concerns are that of policy, compliance, risk, etc. It's not that they "don't care" about the threat, but they don't look at it the same way as a network engineer or sys admin. All said, that's my personal experience and what would lead me to pick Answer A.

comments.content:
A. The organization has accepted the risks associated with web-based threats.
Note: "the organization" not the "security analyst" not the "team lead" not the "systems engineer" not the "sys admin." 
Again, difficult to believe an *organization* would just accept any kind of risk from a web-based threat.

discussion.content:
Hard to believe an organization would just accept any kind of risk from a web-based threat. Such risks might include ransomeware. Nobody just accepts that. If the team lead is unconcerned, then the threat must already be mitigated. 
Putting web-based applications are on isolated network segments, would not help much. Since the applications are on the web, the applications can still be attacked.
Updating the NIPS signature every hour would defend against "a new attack method on web-based applications was publicly revealed"

choices.B: The attack type does not meet the organization's threat model.
choices.D: Corporate policy states that NIPS signatures must be updated every hour.
choices.C: Web-based applications are on isolated network segments.
choices.A: The organization has accepted the risks associated with web-based threats.

questions.question_text: A systems security engineer is assisting an organization's market survey team in reviewing requirements for an upcoming acquisition of mobile devices. The engineer expresses concerns to the survey team about a particular class of devices that uses a separate SoC for baseband radio I/O. For which of the following reasons is the engineer concerned?

choices.B: The organization will be unable to restrict the use of NFC, electromagnetic induction, and Bluetooth technologies
choices.C: The associated firmware is more likely to remain out of date and potentially vulnerable
choices.A: These devices can communicate over networks older than HSPA+ and LTE standards, exposing device communications to poor encryptions routines
choices.D: The manufacturers of the baseband radios are unable to enforce mandatory access controls within their driver set

comments.content: Seems to me the SoC could be managed by the OS. Why not?
How long does a typical mobile device last anyway? Three years? Maybe even less. Lots of people trade in their phones every two years, maybe even every year.

discussion.content: I would lean more towards C. The separate system-on-a-Chip would be vulnerable down the line as it is not managed by the device OS...

choices.C: The data represents part of the disk BIOS.
choices.A: The hard disk contains bad sectors
choices.D: Sensitive data might still be present on the hard drives.

discussion.content: Anyone have a good source that reflects why A would be the answer? I can't find anything and am leaning toward D.

bad sector = unusable memory location. if that was really with bad sector, there won't be a value of "qjkehd" be seen. "qjkehd" is shown = no bad sector. 
answer D.

"perform a seven-pass wipe and an additional pass to overwrite the disk with zeros. The company has also instituted a policy that requires users to erase files containing sensitive information when they are no longer needed."

if still got issue, its issue with the hard disk, so bad sector would be apt answer

comments.content: can't a bad sector contain sensitive data? In this case D should be the answer.

discussion.content:
D1960 - this is a tricky one. Answer A (bad sectors) because of very granular knowledge of how bad sectors work... check out the link below, but in short - bad sectors cannot be zeroed out and they are moved/replaced with spare sectors from the spare sector pool. These will appear at the end of the drive space due to "re-mapping".
D1960 - this is a tricky one. Answer A (bad sectors) because of very granular knowledge of how bad sectors work... check out the link below, but in short - bad sectors cannot be zero'd out and they are moved/replaced with spare sectors from the spare sector pool. These will appear at the end of the drive space due to re-mapping.
https://www.mjm.co.uk/articles/bad-sector-remapping.html

comments.content: Good source to learn about bad sectors, but it doesn't really explain why it would be the answer here.

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Sensitive data might still be present on the hard drives ?
I don't see why an auditor would care about a few bad sectors. Why would that be reported? No reason to think the data is part of the disk's BIOS. No reason to think the disk has been degaussed, or to care. The auditor is there to make sure the application works as expected.

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator has installed a disk wiping utility on all computers across the organization and configured it to perform a seven-pass wipe and an additional pass to overwrite the disk with zeros. The company has also instituted a policy that requires users to erase files containing sensitive information when they are no longer needed.
To ensure the process provides the intended results, an auditor reviews the following content from a randomly selected decommissioned hard disk:
//IMG//

Which of the following should be included in the auditor's report based on the above findings?

The Chief Information Officer (CISO) is concerned that certain systems administrators will privileged access may be reading other users' emails. Review of a tool's output shows the administrators have used web mail to log into other users' inboxes.
Which of the following tools would show this type of output?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The email access events should be logged, and so should be found in the log analysis tool.
The two contenders for this question are A and D. A file integrity monitoring tool, however, is used more for monitoring of system files, while the Log analysis tool does exactly what it sounds like.
